description: From Middle English striden, from Old English strīdan (“to get by force, pillage, rob; stride”), from Proto-Germanic *strīdaną. Cognate with Low German striden (“to fight, to stride”), Dutch strijden (“to fight”), German streiten (“to fight, to quarrel”).

verbs.description: stride (third-person singular simple present strides, present participle striding, simple past strode, past participle stridden or strode or strid)

examples: Mars in the middle of the shining shield / Is grav'd, and strides along the liquid field.

entries.meaning: To stand with the legs wide apart; to straddle.
To pass over at a step; to step over.

description: From Middle English stride, stryde, from Old English stride (“a stride, pace”), from the verb (see above). Doublet of strid.

entries.meaning: (countable) The distance covered by a long step.
(countable, computing) The number of memory locations between successive elements in an array, pixels in a bitmap, etc.
examples: This stride value is generally equal to the pixel width of the bitmap times the number of bytes per pixel, but for performance reasons it might be rounded  […]

entries.meaning: (uncountable, music) A jazz piano style of the 1920s and 1930s. The left hand characteristically plays a four-beat pulse with a single bass note, octave, seventh or tenth interval on the first and third beats, and a chord on the second and fourth beats.
